column2: officially the City of Cotabato (Maguindanaon: Ingud nu Kutawatu; Iranun: Inged a Kotawato;Tagalog: Lungsod ng Cotabato )
column3: is a 3rd class independent component city in the province of Maguindanao
column4: Philippines
column5: in the Bangsamoro region. According to the 2015 census
column6: it has a population of 299
column8: making it as the most populated city under the independent component city status.

column1: Cotabato City was formerly a part and the regional center of Region XII
column2: but due to the ratification of the Bangsamoro Organic Law
column3: it is now part of Bangsamoro and serves as the regional center. Being an independent component city
column4: it's not a subject to regulation from the Provincial Government of Maguindanao where it is geographically located. The Philippine Statistics Authority also lists Cotabato City as statistically independent.Cotabato City is distinct from and should not be confused with the province of Cotabato.

column1: Prior to the arrival of Hindus and Muslims
column2: the city was a vast swamp and rainforest landscape where numerous ethno-linguistic groups lived. Maguindanao vernacular architecture developed during this era
column3: which included the architectural techniques of at least 10 ethno-linguistic groups. Later on
column4: Hindu traders arrived and the people of the area embraced the practice of Hinduism. The set of moral standards and culture of present-day people of Maguindanao are seen due to this Hindu influence.

column2: after a successful Islamic colonization in Sulu
column3: Muslim traders went to Maguindanao and converted many of the natives to Islam. Those that did not accept the arrival of the Muslims went into higher ground or the interior of the island. During the same year
column4: the Sultanate of Maguindanao was formally established
column5: with Kota Wato as its capital
column6: and ruled a vast territory in Mindanao from until its total collapse in 1888.

column1: Following the Spanish evacuation in Jan. 1899
column2: Datu Piang led the Moro's in a massacre of the remaining Christian community
column3: enslaving those they did not kill.  Americans arrived in Mindanao in 1900 after the Spanish–American War ended in 1898. Cotabato town was part of Moro Province and of Department of Mindanao and Sulu from 1903 to 1920
column4: when the Empire Province of Cotabato
column5: referred to as "Moroland" by the Americans
column6: was founded with the town as the capital
column7: with Datu Piang as its first governor.

column1: Several towns were carved off from Cotabato town since the year 1913
column2: with Pikit being the first one founded by Cebuano Christian colonists. Dulawan (now Datu Piang
column3: Maguindanao) and Midsayap were incorporated as regular municipalities in 1936. In 1942
column4: at the beginning of the Pacific Front of World War II
column5: the Japanese Imperial forces entered what is now Maguindanao province. In 1945
column6: Maguindanao was liberated by allied Philippine Commonwealth troops and Muslim Maguindanaoan guerrilla units after defeating the Japanese Imperial forces in the Battle of Maguindanao during the Second World War. On August 18
column8: just two years after the Second World War and a year after the official inauguration of Philippine independence
column9: the number of towns in the gigantic Cotabato province were multiplied by Executive Order No. 82 signed by President Manuel Roxas
column21: a total of eleven (11) towns added to the previous four towns; the newly founded towns of Kabuntalan
column23: and Glan added up on September 30
column24: 1949. More and more newly created towns added up in the province's number of towns as the province entered the second half of the 20th century.

column1: The city was chartered by the virtue of Republic Act No. 2364 on June 20
column2: 1959.The city used to be part of the original Province of Cotabato and was its capital from 1920 until 1967
column3: a year after the separation of South Cotabato; since then the city was the administrative center of the ARMM when Maguindanao was carved out in 1973. However
column4: the city broke off administratively from Maguindanao as it rejoined Soccsksargen in the 1990s. Now many sources consider the city as part of the present Cotabato province
column5: although geographically it is still considered part of Maguindanao.

column1: The city has traditionally resisted efforts for its inclusion to the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao despite serving as the government center of the region. Despite of this
column2: the city's residents voted for their locality's inclusion in the new Bangsamoro Autonomous Region by voting to ratify the Bangsamoro Organic Law in the January 21
column3: 2019 plebiscite. The city became the government center of the new region.

column2: 294.4 kilometres) from Manila
column3: the country's capital
column4: and is bounded by the municipalities of Sultan Kudarat to the north—with Rio Grande de Mindanao separating the two—Kabuntalan to the east
column5: and Datu Odin Sinsuat to the south. The city faces Illana Bay
column6: part of the Moro Gulf

column1: Cotabato City has a total land area of 176.0 square kilometres (68.0 sq mi)
column2: located at the mouth of the Rio Grande de Mindanao and Pulangi River.

column1: Cotabato City has 27 urban barangays that are grouped into two major urban areas

column1: The city is situated in the lowest portion of Maguindanao province. The City of Cotabato with its 37 barangays spans an area with marked landscapes of flat
column2: level to nearly level
column3: very gently sloping to gently undulations to moderately sloping or rolling. It is basically a delta formed by two big rivers
column4: the Tamontaka River and the Rio Grande de Mindanao. Basically 70% of its total land area is below sea level. There are only 2 existing elevated areas in the city
column5: the PC Hill and the Timako Hill with an altitude of 90 and 150 feet
column6: respectively.

column1: Concentration of settlements and other urban uses are in the central portion while the southwestern and southeastern portion have mixed uses of agricultural land settlements. The city is criss-crossed by meandering and braided creeks and rivers like the Matampay
column2: Parang
column3: Timako
column4: Esteros and Miwaruy.

column1: These water bodies serve as sources of both agricultural
column2: industrial and domestic water requirements of some rural barangays. These rivers also serve as the natural drainage flow of the city's wastes.

column1: Cotabato City is politically subdivided into 37 barangays. Cotabato City has 27 urban barangays as classified by Philippine Statistics Authority.
Under the Köppen climate classification system
column2: Cotabato City features a tropical rainforest climate (Af)
column3: falling just short of a tropical monsoon climate (Am).

column1: The majority of the inhabitants of Cotabato City are Maguindanaon
column2: comprising about 50% of the city's population. There are sizable ethnic populations of Cebuanos (14%)
column3: Tagalogs (9.7%)
column4: Iranun (7%)
column5: Hiligaynons (5.6%)
column6: Binisaya (2.7%) and Chinese (2%). The remainder of the population belongs to other ethnicities (e.g. Tausug

column1: The main language is Maguindanao. Tagalog
column2: Chavacano
column3: and Cebuano are spoken by both Christians and Muslims
column4: while Iranun
column5: Maranao
column6: English
column8: can also be heard in the city. The dialect of Chavacano native to Cotabato City is referred to as Cotabateño.

column1: As reported by Philippine Statistics Authority (PSA) on 2015

column4: Maranao
column5: and Tausug people. The remaining proportion belong to non - Islamic belief such as Christianity
column6: Buddhism and other sects.

column1: === Cotabato City-Kidapawan City (CK) Agri-industrial and Eco Tourism Corridor ===
Is an Agri-industrial and Eco Tourism Corridor projected by the NEDA region 12
column2: the primary growth node in this corridor is Cotabato City with Kidapawan City and Midsayap as intermediate urban centers.

column1: Tantawan Park- A monument to Sultan Ditapuan Kudarat at the foot of the colorful houses in Pedro Colina Hill. Sultan Kudarat is the 7th ruler of the Maguindanao Sultanate was instrumental in the expansion and rise of the Sultanate and feared by the Spanish colonizers.

The Church of the Immaculate Concepcion Tamontaka - Tamontaka Church was the center of Jesuit evangelization in the late 19th century and the original structure was built in 1872 along the banks of the Tamontaka River.

column2: Juan Arellano and built in the 1940s. It is now a small museum as well as visitor information center of the city.

column2: which is celebrated in honor of Shariff Mohammad Kabunsuan

column4: certain presentations are performed such as dances. There are also many recreational activities and sports. Highlights in this festival are Dance Parade
column5: Banca Race and the re-enactment of Shariff's arrival.

column1: Araw ng Kutabato (Cotabato Day) – celebrated every June 12–25
column2: this is the biggest celebration in all of the city's festivals. This festival is held to commemorate the city's charter day.

column1: Pakaradjaan Festival - A regional wide festival and held in the ORG compound in Cotabato City
column2: Pakaradjaan is a generic term for celebration among ethno-linguistic tribes in the island provinces of Basilan
column3: Sulu and Tawi-Tawi and the Mainland Provinces of Lanao Del Sur and Maguindanao in the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao.The festival shall be capped off with the setting up of intricate mock tribal villages inside the 32-hectare ARMM capitol southwest of Cotabato City to educate tourists on the ethnicity of Muslim
column4: Christian and Lumad people in the autonomous region.
